references:
In multi-sensor fusion based on SL opinions, the cumulative fusion operator â¨direct-sum\bigoplus is often used.
It accumulates evidence in the evidence space and can handle conflicting informationÂ [11].
Due to the accumulation, the uncertainty is reduced with every fusion of opinions, even when fused opinions are in conflict.
As a reference, the fusion of two conflicting opinions, of two supporting opinions, and of an one with a neutral opinion, are visualized in Fig.Â 4.

First, the conflict-aware classification of cells in an evidential grid map is proposed.
In this work, the adaptive patched grid map from [9] is used, in which the state of each cell is modeled by a binomial opinion Ï‰â€‹(mi)ğœ”subscriptğ‘šğ‘–\omega(m_{i}) as stated in DefinitionÂ 2.
Here, the measurements of different sensors are fused by cumulative fusion as shown in Fig.Â 4.
Hence, in this work, the already fused data is used.

references: For the evaluation of the proposed methods, the parameters from TableÂ I are used.

Further, some environments induce conflicting cells inherently without errors in the sensor setup, which is shown in Fig.Â 10b.
Here, the angular resolution of the LiDARs was decreased by reducing the points per second (PPS) of the LiDARs from Pâ€‹Pâ€‹S0ğ‘ƒğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘†0PPS_{0} to Pâ€‹Pâ€‹S1ğ‘ƒğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘†1PPS_{1} by a factor of four as stated in TableÂ I.
Now, the thin poles of fences at the side of the road are not reliably detected by the LiDARs as some rays pass the gaps of the fence without colliding with them, leading to conflicting measurements.
Thus, a degradation score of Î±â‰ˆ0.07ğ›¼0.07\alpha\approx 0.07 is calculated, which shows that even though the sensor setup is working as intended, it cannot measure the environment correctly.
